questions.text: You are counselling parents of a 3-year-old child who recently had first episode of simple febrile seizure. There is no significant past or family history and birth was uneventful. Child is otherwise growing well. What is the likelihood of child developing epilepsy in future?
questions.solution:
Risk of subsequent epilepsy after febrile seizure



KEY TAKEAWAYS: The Risk of subsequent epilepsy after Simple febrile seizure is 1%.

questions.text: A 10-year-old girl has been experiencing recurrent headaches over the last 2 months. There is a family history of migraine in mother. Which of the following is a red flag symptom for headaches that warrants neuroimaging?
questions.solution:
Indications of neuroimaging in children with headache



KEY TAKEAWAYS: Early morning headache is a red flag symptom for headaches that warrants neuroimaging.

choices.text: Smiling for the first time at 8 weeks

questions.text: Which of the following is most suggestive for suspecting cerebral palsy in children?
questions.solution:
Hand preference, or handedness, is the tendency to use one hand more naturally and efficiently than the other for fine motor tasks. This usually develops in early childhood, often becoming clear between the ages of 2 and 4

  • Hand preference or hand dominance before 12 months of age is a red flag sign and needs evaluation.
  • All other development milestone mentioned are achieved at optimal age.

KEY TAKEAWAYS: Identifying and supporting hand preference helps children develop motor skills effectively, which can aid in tasks like writing and drawing as they grow

choices.text: Recurrence within 24 hours of same febrile illness

questions.text: A 4-year-old child is diagnosed to be having complex febrile seizure. Which of the following feature match the diagnosis?
questions.solution:
A complex febrile seizure is a type of seizure that occurs in young children, usually between 6 months and 5 years old, in response to a fever. Complex febrile seizures differ from simple febrile seizures in terms of their duration, frequency, and characteristics, making them more concerning and often requiring closer evaluation.

FEATURES OF COMPLEX FEBRILE SEIZURE

  • Lasting >15 min duration
  • Focal seizure
  • Recurrence within 24 hours of same febrile illness

Incorrect Options:

Option b,c and d: These are the features of Simple Febrile Seizures: Simple febrile seizures are common, benign seizures that occur in young children in response to a fever. These are typically brief, generalized, and do not have long-lasting effects.

  • They are brief, lasting less than 15 minutes usually between a few seconds to a few minutes.
  • Simple febrile seizures are generalized, meaning they involve the entire body. This usually results in rhythmic jerking or twitching movements on both sides of the body.
  • They occur only once during a 24-hour period of a febrile illness.
  • No Focal Features: Unlike complex febrile seizures, simple febrile seizures do not have focal characteristics (affecting only one side or one part of the body). The entire body or both sides are involved symmetrically.
  • Postictal State: Recovery is generally rapid, and children typically return to their normal state quickly with no residual weakness or confusion after the seizure ends.

KEY TAKEAWAYS: Complex febrile seizures differ from simple febrile seizures in terms of their duration, frequency, and characteristics, making them more concerning and often requiring closer evaluation.

questions.text: EEG of which of the following epilepsy syndrome shows centrotemporal spikes?
questions.solution:
• Rolandic epilepsy now called as Benign childhood epilepsy with centrotemporal spikes.
  • It is characterized by focal seizures, where the child wakes up from sleep with focal seizure and preserved consciousness.
  • As the name suggests it is benign condition and resolves with age (mostly by 12 years). EEG shows spikes in centrotemporal regions.

Option B: Landau-Kleffner syndrome has normal EEG findings or Bitemporal discharge.

Option C: Lennox-gastaut syndrome has 1-2 Hz spike-and-slow waves, polyspike bursts in sleep, and a slow background in wakefulness. Point to note is that it is generalized discharge and not focal.

Option D: Juvenile myoclonic epilepsy EEG has generalized 4-5 Hz polyspike and slow wave discharges. Again, a generalized discharge.

KEY TAKEAWAYS: Rolandic Epilepsy is benign condition and resolves with age (mostly by 12 years). EEG shows spikes in centrotemporal regions.

choices.text: A 2 year old child, born at 32 weeks gestation
A 4 year old child, born at term and had birth asphyxia due following obstructed labor
A 14 year old child had significant head injury at 13 years of age
A 12 year old child, who developed kernicterus at 10th day of life

questions.text: Which of the following condition you do not expect risk of developing cerebral palsy?
questions.solution:
Cerebral palsy (CP) is a group of permanent neurological disorders affecting movement, posture, and muscle tone, resulting from brain damage that occurs before, during, or shortly after birth.

Risk factors of developing cerebral palsy

  • Prenatal insult
  • Preterm birth
  • Birth asphyxia
  • CNS infections
  • Toxin exposure like bilirubin (Kernicterus)
  • CNS hemorrhage
  • Metabolic disorders

KEY TAKEAWAYS: Cerebral palsy is a non-progressive motor disorder that affects a growing brain. Hence, insult after brain growth is nearly complete, does not cause Cerebral palsy.

questions.text: A 6 year old female presents with recurrent episodes of 'day dreaming'. Parents report during these episodes they are not responsive to any stimuli and then come round and will not be aware of the episode. Similar events are occurring at school. You diagnose the child with absence seizures, which medication would be most appropriate to start?
questions.solution:
• History is typical of absence seizures characterized by brief staring spells, with no awareness. There is associated poor scholastic performance.

Absence seizures, also known as "petit mal seizures," are brief, sudden lapses in awareness, often lasting only a few seconds. These seizures are most common in children but can also occur in adults. Here are the main characteristics:

Key Characteristics of Absence Seizures:

  • Brief Duration: Usually last between 5-10 seconds, rarely longer than 20 seconds.
  • Sudden Onset: The child or adult may suddenly stop speaking or lose focus, appearing to "stare into space".
  • Lack of Response: During the seizure, the person is unresponsive to external stimuli.
  • Automatic Movements: Some individuals may exhibit slight twitching, blinking, or hand movements.
  • Rapid Recovery: After the seizure, the person usually resumes activities immediately, with no memory of the event.
  • First line of management is Ethosuximide in typical absence seizures and Valproate in Atypical absence seizures.

KEY TAKEAWAYS: Absence seizures are brief episodes of staring or "spacing out," lasting only a few seconds, during which a person is unresponsive. They often occur in children and may involve subtle movements like blinking, with immediate recovery and no memory of the event.

questions.text: Which of the following signs is not seen in an infant with raised intracranial pressure?
questions.solution:
Raised intracranial pressure (ICP) in a child is a serious condition where pressure inside the skull increases, potentially due to causes like head injury, brain infection, tumor, hydrocephalus, or bleeding.

Signs of Raised ICP in infants:

  • Bulging fontanelle
  • Sun setting sign- downward gaze of eyes
  • Separation of sutures
  • Progressive macrocephaly
  • Prominent veins of scalp

KEY TAKEAWAYS: Raised intracranial pressure (ICP) in a child is a serious condition where pressure inside the skull increases, potentially due to causes like head injury, brain infection, tumor, hydrocephalus, or bleeding. Signs in children may include headache, vomiting (often in the morning), irritability, decreased alertness, bulging fontanelle (in infants), and sometimes vision changes like double vision or "sunsetting" eyes

questions.text: Brain perfusion pressure equals
questions.solution:
• Cerebral Perfusion Pressure (CPP) = MAP - ICP or CVP (whichever is highest)
  • Cerebral Blood Flow (CBF) = CPP/CVR [CVR = cerebral vascular resistance]

questions.text: Prematurity is major cause of which type of cerebral palsy?
questions.solution: KEY TAKEAWAYS: Prematurity causes Spastic Diplegia.

questions.text: An 8-year-old child presents with high grade fever for 2 days, drowsiness for last 12 hours. On examination, his GCS is 9/15, Vitals are normal. CNS examination is positive for Neck rigidity. His CSF examination was done immediately, that was transparent and on microscopy has 200cells/mm3, with differential of 70/30, protein 60mg/dl, Glucose 66mg/dl (RBS 78mg/dl). What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
• The child in the vignette has acute onset sepsis, involving the CNS guided by neck rigidity. Out of the options most likely the Viral and Bacterial causes usually present as acute illnesses. TB and Fungal has subacute or more likely chronic illness.
  • Further differential can be made from CSF finding of clear CSF with normal Cell counts, normal protein and normal glucose- all indicative of Viral etiology of meningitis.

questions.text: A CNS tumor that predominantly affects the midline vermis, causes hydrocephalus, biopsy shows small round blue cells and Homer-Wright rosettes is?
questions.solution:
• Medulloblastoma is an embryonal CNS tumor, affecting mainly the cerebellar vermis and thus causing ataxia, poor balance and dysmetria.

  • Histologically, there are small round blue tumor cell characterized by Homer-wright rosettes and immunopositivity for synaptophysin.
  • It can cause obstruction of 4th ventricle and thus hydrocephalus.

choices.text: Blood culture with CSF culture via LP
Blood culture with CSF culture via shunt

questions.text: A child with hydrocephalus had undergone a V-P shunt. He developed fever and irritability. A dose of Acetaminophen for fever spikes was given. What is the next step?
questions.solution:
• The child in the question has signs of CNS infection. Best method to confirm this is CSF culture.
  • As the child already has a shunt in situ, it gives us an option to withdraw a sample of CSF via shunt and hence we can avoid an invasive LP procedure.

Incorrect Options: Radionuclide scan and neuroimaging doesn't aid in the diagnosis of shunt infections

questions.text: Which is the most severe type of Spinomuscular atrophy among the following?
questions.solution: KEY TAKEAWAYS: Most severe is Type 0 - incompatible to life - dies in utero

questions.text: Which of the following feature is not expected in a child with Duchenne muscular dystrophy?
questions.solution:
• Gower's sign, waddling gait, frequent falling and clumsiness are all early signs of DMD.


  • Respiratory muscle failure occurs in the late stages and is often the cause of premature death.
  • Hemiplegia is more likely in spastic CP than DMD, DMD would generally be symmetrical rather than 1 sided.

KEY TAKEAWAYS: Important signs to see in DMD:

  • Pseudohypertrophy of calf muscle
  • Valley sign- depression between fibers of deltoid and infraspinatus
  • Tongue hypertrophy
  • Brisk DTR

choices.text: Without assisted ventilation, median age of death is at 12 years
Their child will likely be able to sit but not to walk
Tracheostomy is the only option for survival
Cough is impaired and use of an airway clearance device is recommended

questions.text: A 4-month-old infant presents with choking when taking his bottles, tongue fasciculation, and profound hypotonia. Which of the following would you tell the parents?
questions.solution:
• The infant described in the vignette has spinal muscular atrophy (SMA) type I (Wernig–Hoffman disease) due to presentation as an infant with the above-described clinical features. Cough reflex is expected to be impaired and the use of a cough assist device will help to clear secretions.
  • Without assisted ventilation, children usually die within the first 2 years of life. With SMA type II, the median age of survival is 12 years without assisted ventilation. (option A)
  • In SMA type I, their child will not be able to sit or walk. (option B)
  • Noninvasive ventilation may also be presented as an option in addition to tracheostomy to prolong survival. (Option C)

KEY TAKEAWAYS: Spinal Muscular Atrophy (SMA) is a genetic disorder that leads to the progressive weakening of muscles due to the loss of motor neurons in the spinal cord and brainstem. It primarily affects infants and children, with symptoms such as muscle weakness, poor muscle tone, and difficulty breathing, swallowing, and moving. SMA is caused by mutations in the SMN1 gene, leading to low levels of the survival motor neuron protein essential for motor neuron health.

questions.text: A 12-year-old healthy boy has noticed some muscle weakness. He has experienced increasing difficulty lifting his backpack and walking long distances. He has no trouble with schoolwork, and he continues to play the piano and video games without tiring. His 38-year-old maternal uncle recently became wheelchair bound for unclear reasons. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
• This patient does not have muscle weakness that precludes extended use of distal muscles (hands) or limits his manual dexterity. The child's presentation at age 12 years and a 38-year-old wheelchair-bound maternal uncle suggests a diagnosis of Becker muscular dystrophy.

Option A: Duchene muscular dystrophy has earlier onset and more severe muscle weakness.

Option B: Myasthenia gravis has muscle weakness progressively over the day. The muscle function improves with rest.

Option D: Guillain Barre syndrome has progressive ascending peripheral neuropathy. Starts as a glove and stocking pattern. Later involves respiratory muscles.

KEY TAKEAWAYS: Becker's muscular dystrophy (BMD) is a genetic disorder characterized by progressive muscle weakness and wasting, primarily affecting the muscles of the hips, pelvis, thighs, and shoulders. Caused by mutations in the DMD gene, BMD is similar to Duchenne muscular dystrophy but is typically milder and progresses more slowly. Symptoms often appear in adolescence or early adulthood and may include difficulty walking, muscle cramps, and heart issues like cardiomyopathy

questions.text: An infant with repeated attacks of seizures has hypsarrhythmia on EEG. She is a known case of tuberous sclerosis. Which is the most appropriate treatment?
questions.solution:
• Hypsarrhythmia in EEG is typical of infantile spasms. It is one of the major features of patients with Tuberous sclerosis.

Infantile spasms (IS), also known as West syndrome, are a rare but severe form of epilepsy that typically begins in infants aged 3-12 months. These spasms appear as sudden, brief jerking movements that often occur in clusters, especially upon waking. Symptoms may include the baby bending forward at the waist, extending their arms and legs, or a "jackknife" movement.

KEY TAKEAWAYS: For infantile spasm DOC is ACTH.

For infantile spasm in Tuberous sclerosis, DOC is Vigabatrin.

questions.text: Which of the following complications is not expected in a child diagnosed with neurofibromatosis (type 1) NF-l
questions.solution:
Complications in NF-1

Option A : Learning disability affecting approximately 30%.

Option D : Seizures in approximately 8%.

The cerebral vessels may develop aneurysms or stenosis resulting in moyamoya syndrome. Neurologic sequelae of these vascular abnormalities include transient cerebrovascular ischemic attacks, hemiparesis, and cognitive defects.

Option C : Precocious puberty may become evident in the presence or absence of lesions of the optic pathway tumors.

  • Malignant neoplasms affecting approximately 3% of patients.

questions.text: A 4-year-old boy present to clinic with weakness and increased frequency of falls over the past month. His gait is weak, and Gower sign is positive. Purplish swelling of the eyelids is also noted. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
• Dermatomyositis should be suspected in any child with symmetrical proximal muscle weakness and skin changes.
  • Proximal muscle weakness is manifest by difficulty in standing, getting out of bed, climbing stairs, or combing one's hair.
  • Falls may occur with increasing frequency.
  • Affected children may display the Gower sign, where they use their arms to climb up their legs into a standing position because their proximal musculature is too weak to support standing without assistance.


  • Skin manifestations of Dermatomyositis include a classic heliotrope rash and Gottron's papules.
  • Rash is not a manifestation of Duchenne Muscular Dystrophy.

questions.text: A 10-yr old male child was presented for evaluation of a seizure disorder. On examination a vascular plaque was found along the ophthalmic and maxillary divisions of the trigeminal nerve. The mother informed the pediatrician that the lesion was present since birth and there was no change in morphology. The most likely possibility is
questions.solution:
• Sturge-Weber syndrome has three major features: a red or pink birthmark called a port-wine birthmark, a brain abnormality called a leptomeningeal angioma, and increased pressure in the eye (glaucoma). These features can vary in severity and not all individuals with Sturge-Weber syndrome have all three features.

Option b: Infantile hemangioma: is a common benign vascular tumor that appears as a red or purple mark on the skin in infants, often developing within the first few weeks of life.

Option c: Congenital hemangioma: is a type of benign vascular tumor present at birth, distinguished from infantile hemangiomas by its immediate appearance and behavior. These tumors are typically fully formed at birth and can be either rapidly involuting (shrinking quickly), non-involuting (remaining stable), or partially involuting (showing some reduction in size). Unlike infantile hemangiomas, congenital hemangiomas do not undergo a growth phase after birth.

Option d: Proteus syndrome: is a rare genetic disorder characterized by overgrowth of various tissues in the body, leading to asymmetrical and disproportionate growth. It can affect the skin, bones, fatty tissues, blood vessels, and other organs.

questions.text: The following conditions may present with microcephaly except
questions.solution:
• Dandy-Walker malformation consists of a cystic expansion of the 4th ventricle and causes
  • Rett syndrome is an example of acquired microcephaly and is seen in girls.
  • CRS and Edward syndrome has Microcephaly as one of the features.

questions.text: All the following are features of Arnold Chiari-II malformation except
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • Arnold-Chiari type II malformation is associated with
    • Myelomeningocele
    • Hydrocephalus
    • Herniation of the cerebellar tonsils, caudal brainstem, and the fourth ventricle through the foramen magnum.
